document: This document discusses database normal forms (1NF, 2NF, 3NF, BCNF, 4NF), functional dependencies, anomalies, spurious tuples, and related concepts.

questions.question: A relation is in First Normal Form if it contains only single‑valued attributes.
Spurious tuples occur when a join of decomposed relations returns fewer rows than the original relation.
A functional dependency X → Y is trivial if Y ⊆ X.
The Boyce‑Codd normal form requires that for every non‑trivial FD, the left side must be a superkey.
A table in 2NF can still have partial dependencies on composite primary keys.
Null values are acceptable in normalized tables if they do not cause redundancy.
Lossless‑join decomposition ensures that joining decomposed relations yields the original relation without loss of any tuples.
A multivalued dependency a --> --> b indicates that for each value of a there is at most one value of b.
Every candidate key must be a subset of some superkey.
Transitive dependency A → B and B → C implies A → C.
If a relation violates 3NF because of a transitive dependency, decomposing removes non‑key attributes that depend on other non‑key attributes.
In BCNF, if X → Y holds where Y is not a superkey, the decomposition into R1(X,Y) and R2(R–Y) preserves dependencies.
A relation can be in 3NF but not in BCNF.
The presence of NULL values always indicates an anomaly in database design.
Functional dependency AB → C means that attributes C is functionally dependent on both A and B together.
Lossless join decomposition requires that the intersection of decomposed relations equals the determinant of one of them.
Anomalies can arise when data are not normalized.
If a relation has a composite key, it automatically satisfies 2NF.
The term "spurious tuple" refers to an extra row that appears in the result of a join due to incorrect decomposition.
In normal forms, a primary key must be unique for each tuple.
